chapter.title: Knowledge Editor
chapter.para: The Editor allows users to view, create concepts, modify concepts, classify, create versions, export versions, create value sets and modify value sets. This chapter provides an overview of the Editor layout and details of the editing functionality such as, creating new content, modifying content, and exporting content. All users in Knowledge are able to see changes made by other users in real-time.

The Knowledge Editor is divided into three sections: the Task Pane, the Concept Details, and the Navigation Bar, see :
Task Pane – The Task Pane consists of several tabs that contain the following functionality:
Taxonomy – the Taxonomy tab displays the content in a hierarchical view, and is the default view for the Task Pane.
Sets – create, edit and view value sets.
Search – the search function enables the user to search for specific descriptions, IDs and other values.
Classifier – the user can run the classifier and view results of classification.
QA – data checks on content can be initiated and results can be viewed.
Versions and Export – users with the appropriate permissions can export content and/or create a version.
Briefcase – is similar to a list. Throughout the editor, there are areas that allow users to add concepts to the Briefcase. Users can then view or modify them in the Briefcase.
Concept Details – The Concept Details pane displays details of the concept selected in the task pane.
Navigation Bar – The Navigation bar enables fast access to functions e.g. New Concept, Run Classifier, Modify global display options.
Knowledge Editor Layout

section.title: Taxonomy
section.para: In the Taxonomy view, users can navigate through the concept hierarchy under the taxonomy tree. The Taxonomy also displays the concepts with their parents and their children. Users can traverse the tree by selecting the caret symbol on the left of the tree to display the selected concept's children.

The tree-like structure of the Taxonomy View allows users to navigate content from a top-down view – users can navigate up or down the lineage of the content by selecting the caret symbol on the left. The user can also select to display the Inferred or Stated view of the content (the Inferred view is displayed by default). The inferred view shows the parent-child lineage that is derived by inferences through a set of logical rules and related concepts; the Stated view shows the parent-child lineage that is set by the editor when creating the concept.

section.title: Status
section.para: The Taxonomy Tree can display Active only concepts or both Active and Inactive concepts. Inactive concepts will display in italics. The default is set to display only Active concepts. To see both status types, change the settings under Display Options in the top right hand corner of the Task Pane.

section.title: Refresh the Taxonomy
section.para: The user is also able to force a refresh of the taxonomy by selecting the Refresh button. This is useful when multiple concepts are expanded and the user would like to collapse them all.

section.title: Concept Type – Defined versus Primitive
section.para:
In Knowledge, concepts are created as either a Defined or Primitive.
Defined concept
Defined – A concept that is Defined is represented by a green circle. A concept is considered defined by unique relationships between its relatives (e.g. siblings and parents).
Primitive – A concept that is Primitive is represented by an orange hexagon and signifies that its attributes and parents composing the concept are non-definitive characteristics.

section.title: Linking the Taxonomy View with Concept Details
section.para:
In the Knowledge Editor, a user can connect/link the concept selected in the Taxonomy to the Concept Details Panel, by default the connection or linkage is set. The linkage can be modified by toggling the linkage icon in the upper left-hand corner of the concept details pane, refer to and . When the linkage is set selecting a concept in the Taxonomy View displays the concept in the Concept Details Pane.

section.title: Sets
section.para: The Sets tab allows a user to create, view, and modify both Value and Map sets. A Value Set is a collection of concepts used for a specific purpose (e.g. Wound Color Value Set would contain the concepts needed to describe the color of a wound). A Map Set provides link between one terminology and another (e.g. SNOMED CT to LOINC mapping).

section.title: Creating a Value Set
section.para:
A Value Set, also known as an assemblage or a reference set (refset), contains a collection of concepts used for a particular purpose determined by its author. Value Set Usage
Lateralizable body structure reference set is a SNOMED CT refset that can be used to specify which arm a blood pressure was taken.
There are two ways to create a new value set: selecting New Value Set under the Shortcuts navigation menu, or by selecting the New button under the Sets tab in the Task Pane.

To create a Value Set, select the Sets tab in the left panel, change the View Group to Value Sets and select New to create a concept for the Value Set, see . On the create new value set page (which is the same as create new concept), fill out the information needed, check the box for This concept is a Value Set, and select Create.

simplesect.title: Adding Members to a Value Set
simplesect.para: To add members to a value set, select the value set in the list and then select Edit when viewing the value set's details (located on the top right corner). This will take you to the edit view where concepts can be added to the value set, removed from the value set, or added to the Briefcase, see . If you do not see the members, select the Members tab on the right panel after opening the value set details.
Select Add Member to find concepts to add, select the remove icon to remove them, and select the Add to Briefcase icon to add any of them to your briefcase.
When you are ready to add the concepts in the Value Set Membership Changes list to the Members of this Value Set list, select Save.
If there are any conflicts, error notifications will display the information to help you decide how to resolve them.

simplesect.title: Inactivating Value Set Members
simplesect.para: To inactivate members from a refset, select the Edit Members button when viewing the refset details. This will take you to Edit Mode, where you can remove members from the list by selecting the X icon. The system will display your selection in the list Value Set Membership Changes for review. Press Save to confirm your updates.
Members cannot be removed from the list, only deactivated. A user can reactivate the concept anytime.

section.title: Creating a Map Set
section.para: A map set associates codes that have the same or similar meaning in one system with another. For example, SNOMED CT's code for Vital signs monitoring can be mapped to LOINC's Vital signs with method details panel and Vital signs with smoking status and pain scale [VSP].
To create a map set, go to the Sets tab in the left panel, make sure that View Group is set to Map Set and select New to open the form.
There are 3 tabs in the Concept Details panel for the user to fill out: Definition, Item Fields, and Business Rules.

listitem.para: Definition - Enter the name, purpose, and any additional information that users may need for the new map set. You can add more fields, such as source code version, by selecting the Add More Fields button on the left.

Item Fields - These are column headers to display when you view the map sets. Source Description, Target Description, and Equivalence Type are selected by default, but you may add more fields or rearrange the order of the columns displayed by selecting the Add More Fields to Map Set Items button.
Business Rules - This is a free text comment box for additional information that users may find useful, such as the use case and guidance on when to use the map set.

section.para: After entering all relevant information, press the Save button at the top of the panel. You will add concepts to this set later. The new map set should appear in the left panel's Map Sets list. If you do not see it there, press the Refresh button.

simplesect.title: Adding concepts to a new Map Set
simplesect.para: At this point, make sure that the map set you just created is open on the right panel. Select Edit on the top right corner of the panel, then take a look at the Map Set Items list. There should be a plus-icon you can select to begin adding concepts to the list.

figure.title: Adding Concepts to a Map Set: Step 1

simplesect.para:
After selecting the plus-icon, the list will fill with a row of droplists. Type in the concepts you wish to link as the source and target descriptions. Adjust the equivalence type as necessary, add a comment as needed, and press the Save button to confirm your modifications. Adding Concepts to a Map Set: Step 2
To remove a concept, press the X-icon on the very right of the map set list.

section.title: Search
section.para:
Knowledge has implemented Lucene, an open-source full-text search library, as one of its search engines. A search can be performed using keywords and Lucene query syntax. To begin searching, select the Search tab on the left panel, then fill in the fields as needed. Both Simple Search and Advanced Search use Lucene. For more details on the Lucene search syntax refer to the Lucene tutorial
Simple Search – searches for descriptions that match the search phrase
Advanced Search – refines the search parameters further, e.g. searching for terminology id, description types (Fully qualified name, Regular name and Definition)

section.title: Simple Search
section.para: Terminologies can be searched by keywords under the Search tab in the task pane. Type in keywords in the Search Text field, then select the Search button to start the search, .

Simple Search allows users to search for the keywords typed in the search box. Selecting the search button will return all descriptions that match. Keywords used in simple search are single terms or phrases. A single term is a single word such as test or hello. A phrase is a group of words surrounded by double quotes such as "hello dolly." If a group of words without double quotes are used such as hello goodbye, then the results will display results that contain either “hello” or “goodbye.” Multiple terms can be combined with Boolean operators to form a more complex query. Review Lucene query keyword matchingfor more advanced search syntax.

section.title: Advanced Search
section.para: Search results can be filtered by using the Advanced Search section, see . There are 4 options in the Advanced Search section:

listitem.para:
Search In – This option narrows the search for Search Text to search in concept:
Descriptions will search-in the descriptions of a concept,
Semantics will search the properties of a concept, or
Identifiers searches the alphanumeric IDs of a concept such as an SCTID or LOINC code.
Page size – select the number of results to display at a time.

Description Type – the system restricts the search to a particular description type, such as Fully Qualified Name (FQN), a Regular Name, and Definition if selected. When All Types is selected the search will be performed on FQN,Regular Name, and Definition.
CSV Export – when selected, the search results list will export the results list in CSV format.

section.para: Select the Search button in order to update the results when advanced options are changed.

section.title: Search Results
section.para: The search results are displayed in a list below the search criteria. The default fields displayed in the search results list are Matching Concepts, Matching Descriptions, Terminology Identifier, Status, and Module, see .

section.title: Classifier
section.para: The Knowledge Editor integrates a high performance Classifier called SnoRocket (https://aehrc.com/snorocket/) which supports OWL EL++ and Concrete Domains. The classifier evaluates the stated relationships, based on Description Logics upon which the terminology is defined, and generates the inferred relationships for each concept. The Knowledge Editor displays Stated and Inferred views of the concept in the Concept Details Pane and the Taxonomy displays Stated and Inferred as-a relationships based on the Taxonomy display options.

section.title: Run the Classifier
section.para: There are two areas in the Knowledge Editor interface to initiate classification: the navigation menu Shortcuts and the Classifier tab, .

The first classification will evaluate all concepts in the environment, subsequent classifications will evaluate only modified concepts. The first classification duration will be less than 15 minutes, and subsequent classifications will be less than 10 minutes. A classification has three possible status values: Running, Done, and Failed.

To start classification select the Run Classifier button. An entry will be added to the Classifier Run List. Since the list does not update automatically when a classification is completed, the user can select the Refresh Run List to force an update of the Run List list.

section.title: Classifier Results
section.para: When the classifier has completed, the status will change from Running to Done. A user may view classification results by selecting an entry in the Classifier Run List. The results of classification are displayed on the right in Classifier Details, .

The classifier details will provide a summary at the top and details below of:
Affected concepts - a list of concepts that are changed by the classifier.
Equivalent sets – any defined concepts that have identical relationships.
Orphaned concepts – concepts that are not defined correctly and must be corrected.
Cycles – the classifier finds cycles that would be difficult to find just by looking at the definition of a concept. Cycles are transitive relationships such as: Cycle Example
If concept A's is-a definition is B and B is-a C, and C is-a A, this will flag a cycle error during classification

The concepts under each of these categories are displayed in a list by default. To hide the details of a category, select the caret symbol next to list name to toggle between expanding and collapsing the list view. You also have the option of adding concepts to your briefcase to correct any issues.

section.title: New Concepts
section.para: New concepts can be added to Knowledge in several steps, then classified to create inferred relationships.

To begin creating a new concept, select the New Concept from either the Taxonomy tab or under the Shortcuts menu (see figure ). The New Concept Form should appear in the Concept Panel. How to Add a New Concept: Step 1

On the New Concept form, you must fill out the following informaiton to create the concept:
Parent - Select one or more parents that the concept will be related to. Begin typing to view a list of suggested parent concepts. Select Add Parent to add an additional one.
Concept name - Enter in the new concept's name
This concept is a Value Set checkbox - If you are creating a value set or simple assemblage, check this box, see . Otherwise, leave it unchecked.
How to Add a New Concept: Step 2
Next, press Create to save the new concept. The application will ask you to confirm your changes because new concepts cannot be deleted after creation, they can only be inactivated.

Once the concept is created, the concept will display in edit-mode. Here, the Fully Qualified Name, Regular Name, and Dialects are already pre-filled. Feel free to add additional descriptions or names as needed, add or edit dialects, set active statuses, and more. How to Add a New Concept: Step 3

For advanced users, the Axiom can also be edited. Axioms display the stated and inferred relationships of the concept. To view the available actions, select the Edit icon. Editing Axioms
Press Save at the top of the page to confirm all changes once edits are done.
New concepts can only be found immediately in the taxnomy tree after creation, if the Taxonomy Tree view is set to Statedif the . If you do not see the concept, make sure that the taxonomy tab is displaying Stated concepts, not inferred. If the Taxonomy Tree is set to Inferred run the classifier, refer to and upon completion of classification the concept is displayed in the Inferred view.

section.title: Briefcase
section.para: The Briefcase temporarily holds concepts that can be reviewed and/or edited later. For example, the Briefcase can be used:

listitem.para: To hold equivalent (duplicates) concepts that are flagged as a result of classification. To edit and view the details of the equivalent concept you can add the concept to the Briefcase.

section.title: Adding a concept to the Briefcase from the Taxonomy
section.para: Concepts in the taxonomy can be added to the Briefcase by right-clicking to view the context menu, and selecting Add to Briefcase. Some of the concepts displayed in lists and the Concept Details Panel can also be added by this method.

section.title: Adding a concept to the Briefcase from Classifier Results

section.title: Removing concepts from the briefcase
section.para:
There are two options to remove concepts from the Briefcase:
Remove all concepts in the list by selecting the Select All Items button and then selecting the Remove Selected Items.
To remove one or more concepts but not all concepts from the Briefcase select the box to the right of the concept to be removed and select the Remove Selected Items button.

simplesect.title: Refreshing the Briefcase List
simplesect.para: If you do not see the concept(s) just added, try refreshing the list by selecting Refresh List.

section.title: Context Menu
section.para: A context menu appears when users right-click on the concept name either on the taxonomy tree or in the title of concept details panel . Some lists contain a context menu througout the application.

The context menu contains the following options:
Open concept – opens the concept details information
Open concept in new Concept Viewer – opens the concept details information in a third panel.
Add to briefcase – add the concept to briefcase, which can be viewed in the briefcase tab.
Copy concept, UUID, SCTID, description and SCTID – copies the information described.
Edit concept – opens the concept in edit mode.
Edit concept in new viewer – opens the concept in edit mode, in a third concept details panel.
Clone concept – duplicates the concept information as a new concept.
Clone concept in new viewer – duplicates the concept information as a new concept and opens a new concept details panel.
Create child concept – creates a new child concept with the same information as the selected concept and uses the selected concept as the parent.
Create child concept in new viewer – creates a new child concept with the same information as the selected concept, uses the selected concept as the parent and opens a third Concept Details panel.
Inactivate concept – sets the selected concept's state to inactive. If the concept disappears from the taxonomy, display options are set to not display inactive concepts.
Activate concept – sets the selected concept's state to active. This option is only visible in the context menu if the selected concept is inactive.
